results.title: Weather: hot
results.creator_credit: Caroline Jones and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
An educational series aimed at 6-8 year olds which covers a variety of subject areas such as weather, transport, space, people and celebrations. When it is hot outside, people wear shorts and t-shirts, drink lots of water, and modify their usual activities to help keep cool. The question is why do we do this? Suitable for children aged 3-7, this video describes how changes in weather affect people, plants and animals differently and the different methods each use to adapt and cope with the heat; what a thermometer is and what it does; how to observe and monitor changes in the weather; and why it is important to dress appropriately when it is hot outside. Also briefly discusses the sun as an energy source.

results.title: Celebrations: achievement
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 4-8 narrated by Carolyn Jones showing the different ways that people celebrate achieving certain goals. Following a group of year 7 students to their graduation from school, comparing their preparation and celebration to a group of Police Force cadets preparing to graduate from the Academy. Also discussed is the importance of acknowledging all achievements, no matter how small they may seem.

results.title: Weather: sunshine
results.creator_credit: Janet Lane and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
An educational series aimed at 6-8 year olds which covers a variety of subject areas such as weather, transport, space, people and celebrations. This short video describes how the sun creates shadows on the ground and reflections on the water; how as the world rotates, the sun sets on one side of the world and rises on the other; and how people and animals use the sun differently. Suitable for children aged 3-7.

results.title: Weather: wind
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video for children explains the mysteries of the wind from a child’s point of view - being scared of the wind at night. It tells of the importance of wind for sailing, gliding, balloonists and the use of the winds currents by birds in flight. There are wind storms, wind breaks, named winds, and the usefulness of wind which can carry seeds and clouds. The video ends with the statement of wind, “it can be heard, felt but not seen”.

results.title: Weather: cold
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video for children covers the topic of cold weather. There are scenes of frosty mornings and the reasons why nights can be so cold, especially when they are cloudless. There are ways and reasons to stay warm and how animals like sheep and horses keep warm during the cold months. The video explains how penguins and whales stay warm, mentioning migration and hibernation as ways animals survive the cold weather. Cold weather and seasons are also important to explain why you can’t buy vegetables all year round.

results.title: To kill a child
results.brief_description: Road safety film. Introduces, with apparent casualness, a young couple about to set off on a motoring trip and a little girl at play. Happy and relaxed, they are planning to make the most of a fine day. A few minutes later the child is dead and the holiday makers numb with shock. The very lack of sensationalism makes the events seem real, leaving one with a sense of lives devastated without warning by pointless, avoidable tragedy.
results.description: Road safety film. Introduces, with apparent casualness, a young couple about to set off on a motoring trip and a little girl at play. results.title: Celebrations: New Year
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
Narrated by Eileen Darley, this program aimed at younger children looks at the celebrations surrounding New Year. It explores why people gather on December 31st and outlines characteristics of the event such as the countdown, singing Auld Lang Syne, and making resolutions. As a point of comparison the program then looks at how people in the Jewish tradition celebrate new year, and the celebrations surrounding Chinese New Year, revealing that food plays a major role in both. Suitable for children 4-8.

results.title: Celebrations: christmas
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
Narrated by Eileen Darley, this program aimed at young children looks at the celebrations surrounding Christmas. It follows the signs and symbols that signify Christmas is near, such as shopping, store and street decorations, advent calendars, parades, sending cards, making your own gifts, decorating trees, the importance of being with people you love, and being charitable to those in need. The program also looks at the origins of Christmas trees and cards, and the story of the first Christmas. Delicious traditional Christmas fare from Italy and Germany are also shown. Suitable for children 4-8.

results.title: Mr Gruber's mystery tour
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
Adapted from chapter 4 from the book “Paddington marches on” by Michael Bond. Mr Gruber takes Paddington on a visit to the Wax Museum where Paddington is astonished and amazed at what he sees. Paddington has never visited the Wax Musem before. Narrated by Michael Hordern.

results.title: An Unexpected party
results.creator_credit: Ivor Wood, Michael Bond and FilmFair Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”
When word arrives that Paddington’s Aunt Lucy is celebrating her one-hundredth birthday, the Browns offer to send Paddington home to Lima to visit for the occasion. The Browns are afraid he will leave forever, but he assures them that he will return. Adapted from Chapter 7 from the book Paddington Marches On by Michael Bond. Narrated by Michael Hordern.
